segments.text: As a result of those Carnegie conferences, as I indicated before, I came to know Roger Revell, and because of my work at UCLA with Martin Johnson, I came to have a pretty good association with Scripps people, although I didn't really feel at the time that I wanted to give up
my summer work at the laboratories at Corona del Mar, so I never formally affiliated with them.
But in 54, 55, I took a year's leave, and I think that was the time I got a Ford Fellowship, as a matter of fact.
Yeah, I got a Ford Fellowship at that time, the Ford Foundation, and I wanted to go down to Scripps to work on
certain aspects of zooplankton that I felt would be valuable as commercial-type organisms.

And it was then that a fellow who was president of a company that I better not mention, because I've never had clearance from that group, read about my going on leave and some of the things I was interested in.
In the Los Angeles Times, I read this article, and he made arrangements to come and see me.
He was president of this company.
He had a nice yacht, and he had some high-flung ideas of getting vitamins from the sea.
So I went to Scripps, established myself,
went out on the vessel, collected some samples, began working, when this man appeared at the door and said, I'm so-and-so, I'd like to talk with you.
Could you have lunch?
So we went out and had lunch, and it turns out he was a chemist from Columbia, become the president of this company, and he wanted to get vitamin A from the sea.
And
So I told him I really didn't have that much interest in that topic and didn't know much about it.
Well, we got along pretty well.
So he said, well, what about coming to Catalina on my yacht?
And we'll discuss this on the weekend.
So I went over and had a nice set of small boats.

Had a lot of fun at Catalina Island looking over marine specimens, which served me well later because I had to aid NSF in picking a site for the University of Southern California Marine Laboratory over there.
And I came to know that coast fairly well, in part because of that three-day weekend we spent over there.
But he finally prevailed upon me to read in this topic, and
agreed to pay me just for reading for him.
It was really kind of a silly arrangement, but it worked out beautifully to supplement my salary, which wasn't too great.
And I provided him reports.
And then he asked me if I wouldn't establish an office in his plant.
And he had very nice offices, which I did eventually.
I got in touch with the Ford Foundation,
and said, I have had an opportunity to develop a much more practical kind of problem than I'd ever anticipated.
Would it be all right with you if I switch over to this?
And after some time on the phone, they said, why not?
So I did.
I then got interested in Krill.
These are euphausid organisms in the Antarctic.
And the reason I did is because they had an extremely high vitamin A content in the eyes.
And by the way, it also was the largest euphausid known and still is.
And so I thought, OK, perhaps this will be fine.
This might satisfy this gentleman's needs.
Well, it turns out that he got more and more enthused every time I turned in a report.
So he said, I'm hiring a marine architect who will be your associate.
And what I want you to do is devise a ship that will be ideal for collecting marine organisms for this purpose, a research vessel.
And I want a real one.
Well, we discovered a hull in Long Beach Harbor, which might have been redone.
It was Howard Hughes' old yacht, the Oceanus.
Fantastic vessel, but not really too good for this purpose.
However, in 1950-51, the Danish government had sent the Galatea around the world on a deep-sea expedition
It was led by Anton Bruhn, who was at the Copenhagen University, was curator of their museum, and was himself an ichthyologist.
He led that expedition, which was noteworthy because of many things, but one of them was that it dredged in the deepest trench known in the Pacific.
And it was the first time that they had ever been able to get a dredge that deep.
And they brought up life, definitely proved there was life in the deep sea, in the deepest part of the sea.
At any rate, the Galatea, I learned, was up for sale in Copenhagen Harbor.
So I mentioned this to this man, the vitaminologist, and he said, go.
So the marine architect and I decided we would go.
Well, the Galatea had the largest deep-sea winch then available, and it had also a tapered cable.

That is, it was a very large cable to base, tapered to very fine cable, so that they could have as many miles of cable out as needed to get to the bottom without the cable snapping under its own weight.

Roger Revell, who was then director of Scripps Institution, and who had seen to it that I had adequate space and everything at Scripps to work, commissioned me through the United States Navy to attempt to buy this winch and the cable.
And so I traveled
under the aegis of more than one group, as a matter of fact.
The United States Navy gave me the rank of an admiral, and I traveled anywhere on orders for them in order to do this service.
And I had an excellent experience.
However, I was in and out of Scripps, and really, although Roger
said, I must give you the title of research associate, which gives you a great deal of freedom.
You can represent us officially, but you don't have to do anything.
And so I became the first and maybe the only research associate in Scripps.
But I had a magnificent experience.
I came to know Anton Bruhn very well and Gunnar Thorson.
who was a leading Danish biologist, marine biologist, and came to be world recognized.
And later, of course, he invited me to go to his lab to work at Elsinore, just outside Kronborg Castle.
It was just outside the lab window.
But you see, one thing leads to another.
But that experience was excellent for me.
I got to know many of the then active scientists at Scripps, and I got to know many of the scientists around the world.
Did you purchase the boat?
I placed the order for it.
then resigned.
I never saw it.
They got it, and he gave it, I believe, eventually to Scripps.
I don't remember what the name is now.
No, for many reasons I had to correct.
He wanted me...
He came under the influence of Mr. Merck.
Merck Chemical.
And
ask him what he should do with his business.
He was getting to be alone in years and making fantastic amounts of money.
And Merck had said that what you should do was pick three men and gradually turn the business over to those three men, stock and whatever.
So he called the three of us in individually and then together and said, I picked you three to take over my business.
He was then 70.
And he said, I now want you to get used to living a good life.
And so he began giving us retainers of 2,000 a week.
Gave me a Cadillac, use of his yacht, anything I wanted.
Well, when I went to Europe, I was to entertain
the near great or the great anywhere that I could, which we didn't do.
I wasn't geared to that kind of life.
Nor was I geared to the other.
So I told him in a long letter from Europe that when I came back, that I had discharged what I said I would do.
I had got plans through.
Stokkenwerft Shipyard in Hamburg, and I let
It would have been a nice life, you know, in a way.
I would have inherited quite a fortune.
But I was somebody he liked particularly.
He looked upon me as his son and stuff.
But it wasn't the life.
So.
What became of whatever research that there was that you were supposed to be involved with?
Well, about all I did was write a paper, which was published in Scientific American in 1958.
and which Scientific American told me the other day has sold more than any other.
They've sold 124,000 copies of that alphabet.
It was on whales, plankton, and man.
Remember that crazy thing?
That appeared in an English text.
It's used in a freshman English reading book, as a matter of fact.
And it's been two or three times published in various books.
I don't know.
It was one of those things I thought was fascinating.
There's some mistakes in it, a lot of other things.
But at any rate, it worked out pretty interestingly.
But that was what I did, was delivered a lecture.
I was invited to give a faculty lecture at Caltech one afternoon.
And they said they wanted something that the Caltech people ordinarily didn't hear.
So I decided to do that.
And I wrote this.
Well, the kind of thing they got then was, to a great extent, molecular kinds of things.
And so I decided to put that manuscript together and deliver a lecture on it.
I was also writing it up.
in a little more technical vein.
When I finished, a man came up and said, Gerard Peel, who was a publisher of Scientific Americans, a good friend of mine, and he really ought to have that manuscript.
He said, that's something that ought to be published.
That's really interesting.
So, you know, they didn't have any referent against which to judge it outside of the fact that this was interesting to them.
So I said, fine.
Before long, I got a call from Flanagan, who was the editor of Scientific American, and said, I understand you've got this.
Would you mind sending that manuscript to us?
And I said, no.
I'll send it.
So I sent it.
In about two weeks, I got a check for $400.
And I said, good God.
I didn't know Scientific American paid for articles.
So I got this check with a letter saying, we're going to find a place for this in the next year or so.
We want it.
Well, two weeks later, I got a frantic call saying, where can we get some artwork?
We're going to put that article in right now.
That was in November of 58, I think, and the thing came out in December issue, so it went fast.
Why, I don't know.
But I then got calls from all over the world about that.
Is this thing really edible?
Is it good?
Would it be useful?
All this kind of stuff.
And from shrimpers down here, afraid the shrimpers were going out, they wanted to know could they take their shrimp fleets and go down there and get these things.
So it went.
And the last call was from Jacques-Yves Cousteau asking where he could get krill in largest amounts two years ago, just before he went to Antarctica.
But they're still selling it.
They're still selling it.
As a consequence,

Freeman, who's been publishing the book, the publisher, phoned the other day and asked if I would now edit a series of off-prints in a coherent group for them on the natural history of marine organisms, you know, putting a lot of them together as a package.
And I said then, hey, how's Wells Plankton and Mann doing these days?
He said, I got to.
I got, I think, a half cent for each one.
I usually get a check for $100 or $120 every year.
It doesn't mean anything, but they've been selling a lot of them.
He said, hey, still one of our best sellers, except they're around $124,000.
So that's how that thing came about.
And today, of course, the Japanese and the Russians are fish and krill in the Antarctic.
And El Sayed here has much more interest in the Antarctic than I do, so he's got that end of the scale.
But I tell you, when I went to Europe trying to convince the Norwegians, I wanted the Norwegians, who were then the great whalers,
to give me one of their whale catchers and part of the time on their factor ship to harvest krill.
The man radar, or sonar, was just coming in as a result of its development during the war.
And they were using that to try to detect whales and the krill was getting in their way.
It was noise.
And I learned something.
They said,
You may not know it, but the British owned all of the Norwegian wedding fleet.
So I went to England and got nowhere.
They had money coming in.
They weren't interested in anything else.
That's when I realized that, although my mother was British, that British don't have as much imagination in financial things that you would like sometimes.
I think this has been borne out in more ways than one.
They just turned me down flat and said, it's a dream.
And we've got the real thing now.
So they entertained me royally, but I never got into it.
But now it is important and may prove to be even more important.
What we need now, of course, is much more in the way of studies than we've ever had before.
There are men who knew so much more than I did about this.
I visited with them at the National Oceanographic Institute at Wormley.
in England and the British Museum and so on.
But no one of them then saw this potential.
They didn't see it at all.
For some reason, I don't know.
But we need studies now to really be sure how much that stock can sustain because it is good food.
And there's no reason in the world why
It shouldn't have really, and what I tried to entice them with, should become a gourmet food.
By the way, have you seen this book by Muriel L. Gouberlet in 1964 on explorers of the sea, famous oceanographic expeditions?
Yes.
My wife wanted to be sure that you saw that.
We have not read it.
Well, she thought maybe you might get some ideas out of it.

At any rate, she thought it was also interesting that we both came up with this idea that a hundred years ago, on the 24th of May, the Challenger expedition returned to England after its three and a half year of launch.
And that is darn interesting.
You can have that if you want.
I think I had the book in my office, but just in case I don't, Monty may have to pick it up to look at it.
Uh...
I want to also know about the work with the ONR in 1956 and in 1964.
Did you have two separate grants from the Office of Labor Research?
Oh, yeah, a long period of time I had grants.
Well, there's a book being written now on the history of scuba diving in the United States.
And they're going to start the history of 1950.
But actually, it started earlier than that.
Outside of the military, I think I bought the first scuba gear that was used in this country.
And here's the way it came about.
And that's why the Navy got involved.
I was then editor of a very Mickey Mouse small journal that had had a long and distinguished history, but was getting a little out of date.
It didn't have enough budget to compete.
It was called the Journal of Entomology and Zoology, which had been started in the turn of the century at Pomona College.
And there were a lot of good things that had been published in it.
in a period of time, some 50 years.
But it had been particularly important for exchanging with European journals, free exchange.
And the library at Pomona College had more foreign journals than many universities.
But as an editor of that magazine, I was approached one day by a Frenchman by the name of Rene of Westwood.
village outside of UCLA who had a big sporting goods store.
He was a friend of Jacques Cousteau.
And Jacques had asked him if he would merchandise this thing that was called the Aqualon.
It was then the regulator was fabricated in France and the tanks in Canada.
This man phoned me, this Rene, and said, would I carry an advertisement in the journal for his aqualung?
And I said, gee, what is it?
He said, it is an underwater breathing apparatus.
It was not then called scuba.
And it will permit one to stay underwater for several minutes, up to half an hour, depending on depth.
free diving.
So I said, well, I certainly couldn't do that.

But click, click, click, in my mind was, man, if you could really do this, how nice it would be in summer sessions when I needed marine specimens to work with and experimental embryology and so on, to be able to go out any time and not wait for a low tide.
So I said, I will carry your ad if and only if I approve of this device in the swimming pool.
at Pomona College.
So he said, I'll be out the next day before he came.
I strapped one of these things on, and I saw the potential was magnificent.
And so I bought it and began using it at Corona Del Mar.
I used it about the last of my life several times because, of course, you had no buddy system.
Nobody else had one around.
That was 1948.
Fortunately, I advertised it in the journal, and the first ad appeared in
48, 49 academic year.
Well, I then began going off the coast.
And I found things in the underwater environment that I just didn't know existed there.
And nobody else did, even though many good biologists had been along that coast for 50 years.
I saw things they had never seen, didn't even think existed there.
So I wrote the Office of Naval Research about this.
And Sidney Galler, who is now, I think, one of the assistant secretaries of commerce, was then in head of the biological section of the Office of Native Research.
And I said, you know, I think this has great potential.
And I have a problem I would like to work on there.
There's some rock material under there that I'd really like to examine very thoroughly.
and this makes it possible to do it quantitatively, and so on.
So he came out to California, and we discussed this, and they gave me grants.
And then I went on with that for some time.
And later, when I came here, when I went to NSF, of course, it all had to stop.
When I came here, the Navy,
not only gave me grants to go on with that, but they also gave me grants to work in the deep sea.
And they did this until it became very evident that the action in the United States was going to be on the Commonwealth shelf.
Everyone was coming to be interested in the Commonwealth shelf.

So I'm very glad I had my chance in the deep sea, and this book I look upon as being something that I've just got to put, because 14 or 15 cruises on the Gulf of Mexico can't go without some kind of recording.
But it's a hell of a job getting all this stuff identified.
There's no way to do it easily and quickly.
But my wife and I have had, as a result, we've picked certain groups of organisms that we had to work with.
And we've made a lot of good friends around the world as a result.
In Japan, France, we've had French scientists visiting us, Japanese and so on, as a result of this work.
We specialized in the crustaceans.
It's given my wife something she likes to do.
And so we are really most appreciative of the great support that ONR gave us.
I hate to see ONR go down the tubes.
Well, is ONR going down?
Well, it's hard to say.
They certainly, I have not felt in good confidence I could ask them for any more money for seven years.
But part of the reason for that was that Senator
I've forgotten who it is now.
I wanted to say Magnuson, but it's not Magnuson.
From Montana, whatever his name is.
Mahoney?
No, not Mahoney.
It begins with M, though.
At any rate, he indicated that ONR should not support any but missionary research.
Research directed toward the mission of the Navy.
This came to be acoustics.
And they asked me if I could in any way turn my work into acoustics.
And I tried one year, and my heart wasn't in it.
What is acoustics?
Transmission of sound in the sea and those factors, biological and otherwise, that cause aberrations in sound transmission.
But ONR has been cut down, and there's been some long debate as to whether it would actually continue.
Part of the reason for the problem is that the Navy wants to move that part of the Office of Naval Research to Bay St. Louis, Mississippi.
And there's been a great fight against it.
Whether that will be done or not.
Are you conversing with them?
Did you know this?
You know NASA had that big installation over there that they built and never used?
It's a gigantic installation.
Magnificent computer center.
All the Washington people feel it's in the backwash of the world, and they don't want to go.
So ONR may come to a gradual stop.
